Visible-light photocatalytic reduction of Cr(Ⅵ) using nano-sized delafossite (CuFeO2) synthesized by hydrothermal method
Qiupeng Xu a, b, Ruizhen Li a, *, Chengduan Wang c, Dong Yuan a
a School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Sichuan University of Science and Engineering, Zigong 64300, Sichuan, PR China b School of Chemical Engineering, Sichuan University of Science and Engineering, Zigong 64300, Sichuan, PR China c School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Sichuan University of Arts and Science, Dazhou 635000, PR China

Keywords: Nano-sized CuFeO2 Cr(Ⅵ) Visible-light photocatalytic reduction P-type semiconductor
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: liruizhen007@163.com (R. Li).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jallcom.2017.06.243 0925-8388/© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
Developing p-type semiconductors by using simple and reliable synthesis procedure is a promising way to expand the field of photocatalytic application in fuel production and photo-reduction of inorganic contaminants. Herein, a potential p-type semiconductor, nano-sized CuFeO2 with large specific surface area and excellent photocatalytic activity was successfully synthesized by hydrothermal method. Various physicochemical and photoelectrochemical properties of this material were investigated. The asprepared nano-sized CuFeO2 was verified to have a bandgap energy of ca. 1.15 eV and a more negative conduction band edge than the reduction potential of hexavalent chromium (Cr(Ⅵ)). It is thermodynamically feasible for using as-prepared nano-sized CuFeO2 as a photocatalyst to reduce Cr(Ⅵ) under visible-light irradiation. To find the optimal operation condition of photocatalytic reduction procedure, the essential influencing factors in terms of initial concentration of formic acid (hole scavenger), pH, and the dosage of nano-sized CuFeO2 were studied. Compared with micron-sized CuFeO2, as-prepared nanosized CuFeO2 exhibits better photocatalytic performance for Cr(Ⅵ) reduction. The reduction efficiency on nano-sized CuFeO2 reaches 96% within 60 min. Moreover, the proposed mechanism of photocatalytic reduction process was also discussed in this work.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
As a promising green technique for solar energy utilization, semiconductor photocatalysis has attracted considerable concern in environmental purification, in particular, the decomposition of organic pollutants and disinfection. In the last decades, notable progress has been made to successfully photodegrade organic pollutants based on n-type semiconductor materials such as TiO2 [1], ZnO [2], CdS [3], WO3 [4] and their composites [5e7]. However, further efficient photocatalytic application of n-type semiconductors is still limited due to their large forbidden bands, low quantum yields [8], and unsuitable conduction band edges [9]. It has been proven that it is much potential and promising for developing p-type semiconductors to expand the field of photocatalytic application in fuel production (for instance molecular hydrogen [10] or methanol [11] production) and photo-reduction of inorganic contaminants [12].
A new attractive type of copper-based ternary oxides, CuFeO2, which crystallize in the delafossite structure, has been recently investigated as a potential p-type photocatalyst. Many excellent properties with CuFeO2 are the earth abundant elements composition, a small bandgap [13], and a high energetic position of the conduction band (CB) [14] making CuFeO2 low cost and environmental friendly, can efficiently absorb almost the entire range of visible light, and has a strong reducing power. Moreover, CuFeO2 has better chemical stability under illumination and in aqueous environments than p-Cu2O [15], p-Cu2ZnSnS4 [16], and p-Cu(In, Ga) S2 [17]. It is also not as difficult to be processed as traditional p-type semiconductors such as GaP, GaAs, and GaInP2 [18]. In consideration of aforementioned advantages of CuFeO2, CuFeO2 as a potential photocatalyst has been investigated interestingly in hydrogen evolution [8], removal of various divalent metal ions [19], solar cell [20], and CO2 fixation [21].
Up to now, CuFeO2 has been commonly synthesized by solid state reactions and sol-gel methods which require a hightemperature (more than 850 C), time-consuming (at least 12 h), and oxygen-free (for example, nitrogen gas) calcination process [22,23]. CuFeO2 produced by these methods is mainly in a micron-
sized diameter and of a small surface area [24], which is unfavorable to improve the photocatalytic efficiency. Recently, significant efforts have been devoted to developing simple and reliable synthesis procedures to prepare CuFeO2 with further high performance. Sheets et al. has successfully synthesized micron-sized CuFeO2 by hydrothermal method at 210 C [25]. Nanostructured CuFeO2 has also been prepared in hydrothermal synthesis method by Xiong et al. [26].
In this study, nano-sized CuFeO2 with good photocatalytic activity were prepared by hydrothermal method and utilized as a photocatalyst. Hexavalent chromium (Cr(Ⅵ)), a kind of heavy metal priority pollutant, was selected as the target contaminant for photocatalytic reduction. With high solubility and remarkable toxicity, Cr(Ⅵ) is suspected of carcinogenic and mutagenic properties and has a great hazardous threat to the environment and human health [27]. It has significant meanings to develop a simple and effective strategy to quickly remove Cr(Ⅵ) pollution arising from various industrial processes such as electroplating, textile printing, leather tanning, and paint making [28]. The photocatalytic reduction conditions for Cr(Ⅵ) were investigated systematically to find the optimal condition to remove Cr(Ⅵ) efficiently. Compared with micron-sized CuFeO2, nano-sized CuFeO2 with larger surface area and better adsorption ability presented higher efficiency in photocatalytic reduction of Cr(Ⅵ). Also, the tentative mechanism of photocatalytic reduction process was discussed in this work.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation of nano-sized and micron-sized CuFeO2
sections.text: The nano-sized CuFeO2 was prepared using modified methods reported previously [29]. Briefly, 5 mmol Cu(NO3)2$3H2O and FeSO4$7H2O were dissolved in 20 mL deionized water. Under continuous and vigorous stirring, the clear solution was added dropwise into 30 mL 0.1 mol NaOH. Followed that the solution was treated by ultrasound and then stirring for 30 min, respectively. After being mixed well with 0.5 mL of propionaldehyde, the resulting colloidal suspension was allowed to react at 180 C for 24 h in a 100 mL sealed Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. After being cooled to room temperature, the solid products were collected by centrifugation and washed several times with alcohol and then deionized water, respectively. Finally, the products were dried at 60 C. The micron-sized CuFeO2 were prepared similarly by using Fe(NO3)3$9H2O instead of FeSO4$7H2O as one of the precursors.

sections.heading: 2.2. Characterization of nano-sized and micron-sized CuFeO2
sections.text:
X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded by a Bruker D2PHASER X-ray diffractometer (Bruker AXE, Germany) operating at 30 kV voltage and a current of 10 mA with Cu K-a radiation. The morphology was studied by a scanning electron microscopy (SEM, TESCAN VEGA 3 SBU, Czech). The elemental composition of asprepared samples was investigated by an energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX, Xflash Detector 410-M, Bruker, Germany).
The electrochemical and photoelectrochemical measurements were performed with CHI660E electrochemical workstation (Shanghai Chenhua Instrument Co. Ltd., China) equipped with a three-electrode system consisted of a modified F-doped SnO2 (FTO) working electrode, a platinum counter electrode, and a saturated calomel reference electrode (SCE). The visible light source is a PLSSXE300C xenon lamp (Perfect Co., China) with an optical filter (l > 420 nm). After being pretreated by the previously reported method [30], FTOwas coatedwith 10 mL 5mgmL 1 micron-sized or
nano-sized CuFeO2 in 0.5% chitosan solution and dried. The exposed geometry area of FTO was controlled to be 0.0707 cm2.

sections.heading: 2.3. Photocatalytic reduction of Cr(Ⅵ)
sections.text: Photocatalytic reduction procedure was conducted in a Phchem Ⅲ photochemical reactor (Beijing NBET Technology Co. Ltd., China) equipped with magnetic stirrers. In the middle of the reactor is a 500-W Xe lamp which was used as visible-light source and encapsulated in a cooling quartz jacket. Quartz test tubes used to hold testing solution are placed around the lamp, and the distance between them is 10 cm. In typical photocatalytic reduction experiments, a desired dosage of CuFeO2 was dispersed into 50 mL 5 mg L 1 Cr(VI) solution containing the desired concentration of formic acid as a hole sacrificial agent. Cr(VI) was given as K2Cr2O7. The pH of the Cr(VI) solution was adjusted by adding the appropriate amount of H2SO4 or NaOH. The Cr(VI) solution was placed in quartz test tubes. Before irradiation, the suspension was allowed to reach adsorption-desorption equilibrium with continuous and vigorous stirring for 20 min in the dark. During the irradiation, the suspension was still under continuous stirring. 3 mL suspension was collected and centrifuged to obtain the supernatant every 10 min during the photocatalytic reduction procedure. The concentration of Cr(VI) in the supernatant was detected by using the 1, 5-diphenylcarbohydrazide spectrophotometric method (Chinese National Standard Procedure, GB7466-87).

sections.heading: 2.4. Determination of the point of zero charge of nano-sized CuFeO2 (pHpzc)
sections.text: pHpzc of nano-sized CuFeO2 was measured by the solid addition method [31]. Namely, a series of 50 mL 0.01 M NaNO3 solutions were prepared, and their initial pH values (pHi) were roughly adjusted in the pH range from 4 to 9. After accurately recorded the values of pHi, 50 mg nano-sized CuFeO2 was adding into each solution. The suspensions were allowed to equilibrate for 24 h in a thermostatic water-bath oscillator at room temperature. Then, the final pH value (pHf) of the supernatant obtained by centrifugation from each solution was measured. The results were described as D pH (pHf -pHi) vs. pHi.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterizations of nano-sized and micron-sized CuFeO2
sections.text:
Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of nano-sized and micron-sized CuFeO2. All of the diffraction peaks and relative intensities can be identified by standard crystallographic data (JCPDS card No.390246 and No.79-1546). As can be seen from Fig. 1a, three diffraction peaks at 34.394 , 35.631 , and 40.112 (denoted by “*”) could be indexed as rhombohedral (3R)-type structural CuFeO2 crystal (3RCuFeO2). And four diffraction peaks respectively at 34.962 , 37.517 , 47.534 , and 59.883 (denoted by “#”) could be identified as CuFeO2 with the hexagonal (2H)-type structural crystal (2H-CuFeO2). Other diffraction peaks in Fig. 1a could be assigned to both 3R and 2H phase (denoted by “*” and “#”). All of the above results indicate two structural polytypes (3R and 2H) of nano-sized CuFeO2 had been formed. While, all the diffraction peaks of micron-sized CuFeO2 could be assigned to 3R-CuFeO2 from Fig.1b, indicating as-prepared micron-sized CuFeO2 is a pure 3R phase.
These XRD results are in perfect agreement with SEM results as shown in Fig. 2aed. From Fig. 2a, it can be observed that micronsized CuFeO2 crystallized into rhombohedral morphologies with an average edge length of ca. 1.3 mm. Fig. 2b displays the dispersibility of micron-sized CuFeO2 is not so good, and some individual crystals are in a slightly aggregated state. Fig. 2c and d show that nano-sized CuFeO2 displayed with hexagonal plates and rhombohedral morphologies. The size range of hexagonal plates is from 360 to 500 nm. And compared with micron-sized CuFeO2, nano-sized CuFeO2 have more uniform particle distribution.
EDX was employed to analyze the chemical compositions of nano-sized and micron-sized CuFeO2. Fig. 3 presents the EDX
Fig. 2. SEM images of micron-sized (a and b, SEM magnifications are 30000 and 5000 respec CuFeO2.
spectrum. From Fig. 3, the Cu, Fe, O and Cwere observed clearly. The presence of C could be expected from the conducting resin during measurement. It is evident that both micron-sized and nano-sized CuFeO2 are composed of Cu, Fe, and O. In addition, the atom ration of Cu (22.74 wt.%) and Fe (21.99 wt.%) is nearly 1:1 and matches well with the stoichiometric proportion of CuFeO2.
In order to assess the photocatalytic activity of nano-sized and micron-sized CuFeO2, the transient photocurrent responses of themwere recorded in 0.2 M Na2SO4 at a bias potential of 1 V (vs. SCE). As displayed in Fig. 4, once turning on the visible light, a cathodic photocurrent was generated immediately on both nanosized and micron-sized CuFeO2 manifesting their sensitive photocatalytic activity. The former of which is higher than that of the latter. This result could be attributed to that the larger specific surface area (see Fig. S1 in the supporting information) of nanosized CuFeO2 is favorable to decrease the photogenerated carriers diffusion length, and further lets photo-generated electrons (e ) promptly arrive the interface before recombining with photogenerated holes (hþ) [19]. As shown in Fig. S1, the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of nano-sized and micron-sized CuFeO2 are the typical type Ⅲ isotherm. And the specific surface areas of nano-sized and micron-sized CuFeO2 were calculated to be 2.5 and 0.4 m2/g, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.2. Photocatalytic reduction of Cr(Ⅵ)
sections.text:
Because of the good and sensitive photocatalytic activity of nano-sized CuFeO2, it was applied to photocatalytic reduce Cr(Ⅵ) under visible-light irradiation. And to find the optimal operation condition of photocatalytic reduction procedure, some essential influencing factors were discussed as follows.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Effect of initial concentration of formic acid, pH, and dosage of nano-sized CuFeO2
sections.text:
It is well known that the recombination of photo-generated e / hþ pairs occur readily and weaken the photocatalytic activity of the catalyst. Hole scavenger can react irreversibly with photogenerated hþ and efficiently hinder the recombination of photogenerated e /hþ pairs. Accordingly, the effect of hole scavenger is an important issue. In this work, formic acid was used as a hole scavenger. In order to clarify the effect of initial concentration of formic acid, the photocatalytic reduction of 5 mg L 1 Cr(Ⅵ) was carried out by adding different concentrations of formic acid during the photocatalytic reduction procedure. The pH value was adjusted to 3, and the dosage of nano-sized CuFeO2 was 30 mg. As shown in
Fig. 5, the reduction of Cr(Ⅵ) was promoted with increasing the initial concentration of formic acid from 0 to 0.08 M. By calculation, the reduction efficiency of Cr(Ⅵ) increased from 42% to 99% after 80 min visible-light irradiation. To the contrary, further increasing the initial concentration of formic acid to 0.1 M, the reduction efficiency of Cr(Ⅵ) decreased after 80 min irradiation of visible light. These results may be attributed to that appropriate concentration of formic acid can trap and react with photo-generated holes, improve the separation of photo-generated e /hþ pairs, and finally facilitate the reduction of Cr(Ⅵ). Nevertheless, excess formic acid compete with Cr(Ⅵ) dominantly existed as Cr2O72 , HCrO4 , and CrO42 for the adsorption sites on the surface of nano-sized CuFeO2 and to suppress the reduction of Cr(Ⅵ) [32]. Therefore, the following studies were conducted in the presence of 0.08 M formic acid unless otherwise stated.
Fig. 6 shows the photocatalytic reduction of Cr(Ⅵ) at different pH values. It is clearly seen that the reduction of Cr(Ⅵ) increased extremely with decreasing the initial solution pH value. After 80 min irradiation of visible light, the reduction efficiency of Cr(Ⅵ)
are 99.2%, 55.6%, 13.1%, and 10.2% at pH ¼ 3.0, 5.0, 7.0, and 9.0, respectively. The reduction efficiency of Cr(Ⅵ) at pH ¼ 3.0 is significantly higher than that at pH¼ 5.0, 7.0, and 9.0, indicating the effect of initial solution pH value is remarkable under the experimental conditions in this work. These results may be ascribed to the complicated relationship among the pH value, surface charges of the photocatalyst, and dominating existent species of Cr(Ⅵ). In order to illustrate the relationship and further explain the effect of pH value on the reduction of Cr(Ⅵ), pHpzc of nano-sized CuFeO2was determined. The plot of D pH vs. pHi was displayed in Fig. 7. From Fig. 7, it was obviously observed pHpzc value is approximately 6.3 when D pH ¼ 0. Thus, on the one hand, at pH < 6.3, a large amount of Hþ ions are adsorbed onto the surface of nano-sized CuFeO2, and the catalyst surface is charged positively. In contrast, at pH > 6.3, the surface charges of nano-sized CuFeO2 becomes negative. On the other hand, Cr(Ⅵ) exists in oxyanions as HCrO4 , Cr2O72 , or CrO42 depending on the pH value. On the basis of the acidity constant of Cr(Ⅵ) (pKa ¼ 6.49 at 25 C), in an acidic medium, i.e. below pKa, Cr(Ⅵ) primarily exists as HCrO4 , and finally, converts to CrO42 with increasing the pH [33]. The electrostatic interaction between charged surface of nano-sized CuFeO2 and existence form of Cr(Ⅵ) at different pH values resulted in different dark adsorptions of Cr(Ⅵ) on the active sites of nano-sized CuFeO2. It can be confirmed in Fig. 6 that at acidic conditions, the dark adsorption of Cr(Ⅵ) at pH ¼ 3.0 and 5.0 was 29.5% and 18.4%, respectively. Whereas, with increasing the pH to 7.0 and 9.0, the dark adsorption of Cr(Ⅵ) was decreased to 2.9% and 1.6%, respectively. In addition to the good dark adsorption at acidic conditions, the high concentration of Hþ
ion can also promote the reduction of Cr(Ⅵ) because it is advantageous to forward reactions in Eqs. (1) and (2) [33,34]. However, when at alkaline conditions, the low concentration of Hþ ion restrains the reaction in Eq. (3), and the generated Cr(OH)3 also can precipitate on the surface of photocatalyst to reduce the light harvesting and decline in the reduction efficiency of Cr(Ⅵ) (Eq. (4)) [35]. Consequently, unless otherwise specified, in future experiments, the pH value was adjusted to 3.0 owing to its maximum reduction efficiency for Cr(Ⅵ).

As presented in Fig. 8, within 60 min visible-light irradiation, the reduction efficiency of Cr(Ⅵ) (from 17% to 97%) was dramatically enhanced once adding nano-sized CuFeO2. In addition, the reduction efficiency increased with increasing the dosage of nano-sized CuFeO2 from 5 to 20 mg; regardless the enhancement is not so remarkable. However, the further increase of the dosage of nano-sized CuFeO2 from 20 to 50 mg resulted in the decline of reduction efficiency. These results may be attributed to the fact that in heterogeneous catalytic reactions, the appropriate amount of photocatalyst can provide enough active sites and simultaneously cannot prohibit the penetration of visible light [36]. But if excess photocatalysts were added into the Cr(Ⅵ) solution, particles aggregation would occur and lead to light scattering and screening effects [37], which give rise to low visible-light absorption efficiency of nano-sized CuFeO2 as well as the decrease of photocatalytic reduction efficiency. As a result, the dosage of 20 mg was chosen in the future experiments. The photocatalytic reduction efficiency without adding nano-sized CuFeO2 within 60 min visible-light irradiation can reach 17%. We speculate that the formic acid was directly reacted with K2Cr2O7 and resulted in the reduction of Cr(Ⅵ) due to the strong oxidizing property of K2Cr2O7.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Comparison of nano-sized CuFeO2 with micron-sized CuFeO2 for Cr(Ⅵ) reduction
sections.text:
In order to evaluate the photocatalytic performance of nanosized CuFeO2 towards the reduction of Cr(Ⅵ), micron-sized CuFeO2 was used for comparison. Fig. 9 presents the photocatalytic reduction of 5 mg L 1 Cr(Ⅵ) on nano-sized and micronsized CuFeO2 under the optimal operation conditions (pH ¼ 3.0, 0.08 M formic acid, and 20 mg photocatalyst). Noticeably, in the both stages of dark and visible-light illumination, nano-sized CuFeO2 revealed superior ability for reduction of Cr(Ⅵ) over micron-sized CuFeO2. Within 60 min, 96% of Cr(Ⅵ) could be reduced on nano-sized CuFeO2, which is 1.3 times of that on micron-sized CuFeO2. These results may be attributed to the larger
specific surface area of nano-sized CuFeO2 compared with micronsized CuFeO2 (see Fig. S1 in the Supporting Information), which is beneficial to provide better photocatalytic performance for Cr(Ⅵ) reduction.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Photocatalytic reduction mechanism for Cr(Ⅵ) on nano-sized CuFeO2
sections.text:
For exploring the photocatalytic reduction mechanism for Cr(Ⅵ) on nano-sized CuFeO2, the characteristic energy band structure of nano-sized CuFeO2 was investigated. The UVeVisible diffuse reflectance spectra (see Fig. S2a in the Supporting Information) and linear fitting of ðahnÞ2 vs. hn(see Fig. S2b in the Supporting Information) demonstrated that the band gap energy (Eg) of nano-sized CuFeO2 is direct allowed optical transition [38] and was estimated to be 1.15 eV. The result is agreed well with the previous study [19]. The small bandgap energy and strong absorption in the range of 390e780 nm (see Fig. S2a in the Supporting Information) confirmed the feasibility of using nano-sized CuFeO2 as a photocatalyst under visible-light irradiation.
The critical parameter, flat-band potential (Vfb) (0.5 V vs. SCE), was determined from the Mott-Schottky plot (see Fig. S3 in the Supporting Information). In addition, the conduction band (CB) edge of nano-sized CuFeO2 (ca. 0.49V vs. SCE) (ca. 0.25 V vs. NHE), which was calculated according to the relation (VfbþDE-Eg) [14], is more negative than the redox potential Ered of Cr6þ/Cr3þ couple (þ1.35 V vs. NHE) [39]. Thus, it is verified that Cr(Ⅵ) can be reduced thermodynamically by the photoexcited electrons in the conduction band of nano-sized CuFeO2.
The proposed photocatalytic reduction mechanism for Cr(Ⅵ) on nano-sized CuFeO2 was illustrated in Fig. 10. According to the abovementioned discussion, nano-sized CuFeO2 with small bandgap can efficiently absorb photons and be excited to generate electrons in its CB and holes in its VB under visible-light irradiation (Eq. (5)). Because of the electrostatic attraction between Cr(VI) and nano-sized CuFeO2 with large specific surface area, as well as the facilitation of Hþ ion under optimal operation conditions, adsorbed Cr(VI) can promptly reacted with electrons and be reduced to Cr (III) (Eqs. (1) and (2)). Due to the presence of formic acid, the holes can be captured by formic acid and generate reactive CO$ 2 which have too negative redox potential (E0
CO$ 2 =CO2 ¼ 1:9 V) to
effectively reduce Cr(VI) (Eqs. (6)e(8)) [40,41]. In this case, formic
acid plays a multifunctional role in accelerating the separation of photogenerated charges which is beneficial to the photocatalytic activity of nano-sized CuFeO2, and producing reactive radical. Therefore, Cr(VI) can be highly efficiently reduced to Cr (III) on nano-sized CuFeO2.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, our study demonstrated hydrothermal synthesis of nano-sized CuFeO2 and its thermodynamic feasibility for photocatalytic reduction of Cr(VI) under visible-light illumination. Effect factors studies revealed that the large specific surface area of the photocatalyst, low pH value, the appropriate amount of formic acid and nano-sized CuFeO2 could facilitate the reduction of Cr(Ⅵ). Under the optimal operation condition (pH ¼ 3.0, 0.08 M formic acid, and 20 mg nano-sized CuFeO2), within 60 min visible-light illumination, 96% of Cr(Ⅵ) could be reduced on nano-sized CuFeO2, which is 1.3 times of that on micron-sized CuFeO2. The material appears promising for photocatalytic application in photoreduction and removal of other inorganic contaminants such as various metal ions and nitrate. In addition, the as-prepared nanosized CuFeO2 with large surface area and good adsorption ability are remarkably suitable as a high-efficiency photocatalyst that can be applied in hydrogen evolution, solar cell, and CO2 fixation. The synthesis and application of CuFeO2 and other delafossite-type oxides with controlled size and pure crystal phase are under investigation attempting to further improve the performance of these materials.

metadata.abstractText: Developing p-type semiconductors by using simple and reliable synthesis procedure is a promising way to expand the field of photocatalytic application in fuel production and photo-reduction of inorganic contaminants. Herein, a potential p-type semiconductor, nano-sized CuFeO2 with large specific surface area and excellent photocatalytic activity was successfully synthesized by hydrothermal method. Various physicochemical and photoelectrochemical properties of this material were investigated. The asprepared nano-sized CuFeO2 was verified to have a bandgap energy of ca. 1.15 eV and a more negative conduction band edge than the reduction potential of hexavalent chromium (Cr(VI)). It is thermodynamically feasible for using as-prepared nano-sized CuFeO2 as a photocatalyst to reduce Cr(VI) under visible-light irradiation. To find the optimal operation condition of photocatalytic reduction procedure, the essential influencing factors in terms of initial concentration of formic acid (hole scavenger), pH, and the dosage of nano-sized CuFeO2 were studied. Compared with micron-sized CuFeO2, as-prepared nanosized CuFeO2 exhibits better photocatalytic performance for Cr(VI) reduction. The reduction efficiency on nano-sized CuFeO2 reaches 96% within 60 min. Moreover, the proposed mechanism of photocatalytic reduction process was also discussed in this work. © 2017 Elsevier B.V.
